Looks like everybody is asleep. You are wrong about this circuit. The IC is a combined buck/boost IC with charging function. The 12.6V comes from the battery or from the AC adapter. The 12.6V is created by this IC by its buck converter to lower the 19V input voltage in 12.6V. The 4 mosfets are placed in a bridge configuration and by switching the mosfets the output voltage can be changed. There are two current resistors, one for monitoring the input voltage and and a current resistor to monitor

The ME region stands for Management Engine region. It's a part of the BIOS firmware on Intel-based systems that contains the Intel Management Engine (ME) firmware. The ME firmware is responsible for various low-level functions, including system management, security, and remote administration. It operates independently of the main CPU and can perform tasks even when the system is in sleep or hibernation mode.

The ME region is crucial for the proper functioning of the system, and issues with it c

in bios repair  ?
My guess is that while reprogramming itself it reprogrammed all the ICs connected via I2C too.

From [the datasheet](https://www.ti.com/lit/ds/symlink/tps65994ad.pdf): "The TPS65994AD firmware implements a host interface over I2C to allow for the configuration and control of all device options. Initial device configuration is configured through a configuration bundle loaded onto the device during boot. The bundle may be loaded through the I2C_EC port or it may be loaded over I2C3m from an external EEPROM. The TPS65994AD configuration bundle and host interface allow the device to be customi

zed for each specific application. The configuration bundle can be generated through the Application Customization Tool."

From what I can gather, the board engineers use TI's Application Customization Tool to generate a config, which is stored then loaded by the chip from an external EEPROM via I2C3m or from the EC (probably from its own EEPROM) over I2C_EC into its RAM. Theoretically though, this should all just mean that it will configure itself automatically on boot and so there shouldn't be

anything you'd need to do other than replace the chip.

Evidently though, as you said, it's still not working, so maybe there is some serialization information for the chip that the EC reads on first power on after manufacturing and stores or vice versa (see screenshot of register 0x05 that I got from one of the below manuals). TI and the board designers of course have all this info locked up tight under NDA, so either you find a leak or reverse engineer a live board using [this manual](https:/
That code means major failure MB and can be anything.  You also have to check the coils to ground for short. If no short found check the voltages on the coils.

On a modern Intel platform:
1. EC reads the power button going low
2. EC verifies that all power good signals are present
3. EC turns on +1.8 V core logic for the PCH
4. EC waits for the PCH to tell it that its power wells are stable
5. EC asserts `RSMRST` (resume reset) to the PCH
6. PCH replies with `PLTRST` (platform reset, final high-level signal) and takes it from there, reading the main BIOS ROM and starting the CPU

some more info:

- SUS_STAT = 0v (SUS_STAT is connected from CPU_LPC to thinkengine)
- All pins of SPI Flash (Bios) are 0v
- VCC3_SUS = 0v
- SUS_DRV = 0v (VCC3_SUS enable PQ25 gate)
- PQ25 pos MM pin on source, neg on drain, vdrop = 0.52V. neg MM pin on source, pos on drain, vdrop =  0.957v

- EC_RESET = 3.3v
- CLKRUN = 0v (VCC3B = 0v)
- LPCCLK_EC_24M = 0v
- PLTRST_FAR = 0v
- TP4_RESET = 0v
- LID_CLOSE_EC = 0v
- JTAG_RST = 0v
- EC_PWRREQ = 0v
- TBT_RESET_EC = 3.3v

Okay. Let's clarify some things at this point. This is one of the most common and at the same time one of the most complicated faults which exists on Intel platforms.

Namely the Chipset not de-asserted SLP_S5#, SLP_S4# and SLP_3#
Even of the Chipset is in perfect condition it will not work on your board when BootGuard is enabled

There is small chance that it will unlock by itself if you put it into laptop and charge it with lab power supply directly. Sorin has done it few times. But its quite rare. If it's locked also if you can open it up and let's say cells unbalaced. If you balance cells might unlock. Of course if fuse blown have to repair fuse as well. Worth a shot without NLBA if ur desperate. Also by measuring cells directly you get an idea what the cells are doing.

The theory on modern platform is as follows. Main Power Rail up, EC up, Chipset up but just for a moment to sent it back to sleep (DeepSleep). If the Chipset can not send itself into deep sleep, then RSMRST# stays low, therefore the EC staying in reset state, although technically fully functional.

At least not without loading Intel RST driver

* **Function:** This is a high-current (up to 8A) **Synchronous Buck Converter** commonly used on laptop motherboards to generate major power rails, such as the **3.3V and 5V Always-On (ALW or PCU) supply lines** for the system.

The concentrated burn mark indicates a **catastrophic internal failure** of the IC, which may have been triggered by a short circuit on its output or by a failure in one of the external MOSFETs.

Inconsistent issues are normally caused by a bad connection. The source of a bad connection is most likely to be the solder balls beneath a large BGA chip like the CPU because it is the most susceptible to board twisting and general movement. Pressing down helps to temporarily rejoin any cracked balls, which may cause the fault to disappear while it is held.
